verses.text: LORD, remember David and all his hardships;
verses.comment: The psalm begins as a prayer recalling David's suffering and faithfulness. The tradition remembers David’s steadfast devotion, setting the stage for a focus on God’s covenant with David’s line, which is central to fulfillment in salvation history.

verses.text: how he swore an oath to the LORD, and made a vow to the Mighty One of Jacob:
verses.comment: David’s solemn vow reveals both his humility and his awareness of God’s majesty. The reference to 'Mighty One of Jacob' highlights the continuity with the promises to the patriarchs.

verses.text: I will not enter my house, or get into my bed;
verses.comment: David’s resolve shows an extraordinary commitment to the LORD, putting the worship of God even before his own comfort.

verses.text: I will not allow sleep to my eyes or slumber to my eyelids,
verses.comment: David’s vow is depicted in hyperbolic language, emphasizing the intensity of his zeal for the LORD’s dwelling.

verses.text: until I find a place for the LORD, a dwelling for the Mighty One of Jacob.
verses.comment: The language of ‘find a place’ and ‘dwelling’ refers to the establishment of the sanctuary in Jerusalem (the temple). God dwelling among His people foreshadows the Incarnation and the reality of God being present with us.

verses.text: Look, we heard of it in Ephrathah; we found it in the fields of Jaar.
verses.comment: Ephrathah refers to the region around Bethlehem; Jaar is Kiriath-Jearim, where the ark was kept. The retrieval of the ark prepared for God’s dwelling in Zion, linking David’s kingship and worship.

verses.text: Let us go to his dwelling place; let us worship at his footstool.
verses.comment: The language shows the people's participation in worship, highlighting God’s tangible presence among His people. The ‘footstool’ is a reference to the ark, connecting worship with sacred space.

verses.text: Arise, O LORD, and go to your resting place, you and the ark of your might.
verses.comment: This echoes the ancient call whenever the ark set out. The resting place points to Jerusalem as God's chosen dwelling, and ultimately looks forward to the Incarnation where God dwells with humanity in fullness.

verses.text: Let your priests be clothed with righteousness, and let your faithful shout for joy.
verses.comment: Priestly garments symbolized holiness. Here, true righteousness is desired. The role of priests and joyful worshipers connects to the idea of a worshiping community with a special ministerial role, prefiguring Christ’s high priesthood.

verses.text: For the sake of your servant David, do not turn away the face of your anointed one.
verses.comment: 'Your anointed one' refers to both the reigning king (messiah) and prophetically to Christ Himself. God’s promises to David point forward to the eternal kingship fulfilled in Jesus.

verses.text: The LORD swore a sure oath to David, and He will not turn from it: 'One of your own descendants I will set upon your throne.'
verses.comment: This is the messianic promise. God’s faithfulness to His oath anticipates the Incarnation and the everlasting kingdom established by Jesus, the descendant of David.

verses.text: If your sons keep my covenant and my testimonies that I will teach them, their sons also shall sit on your throne forevermore.
verses.comment: The promise is both conditional and ultimately assured in Christ. Obedience brings blessings, but the complete fulfillment comes with Christ, who is eternally faithful.

verses.text: For the LORD has chosen Zion; he has desired it as his dwelling:
verses.comment: Zion is God’s chosen place not just geographically, but as a symbol of His people and presence. The idea of God’s dwelling forms the foundation for the theology of God’s enduring presence within His Church.

verses.text: 'This is my resting place forever; here I will dwell, for I have desired it.'
verses.comment: God’s irrevocable choice of Zion for His dwelling foreshadows the mystery that God desires to be present permanently with His people, a truth fully realized in Christ’s abiding presence.

verses.text: 'I will abundantly bless her provisions; I will satisfy her poor with bread.'
verses.comment: The blessing of bread points toward God’s providence and, in the fullness of time, the spiritual nourishment Christ gives in the Eucharist, the Bread of Life (see John 6:35).

verses.text: 'I will clothe her priests with salvation, and her faithful will shout for joy.'
verses.comment: A repetition with added emphasis: God’s priests are not merely outwardly adorned but robed in salvation—pointing to the inner transformation and joy God gives to His chosen ministers and people.

verses.text: 'There I will make a horn to grow for David; I have prepared a lamp for my anointed one.'
verses.comment: 'Horn' symbolizes strength and kingship; 'lamp' is a symbol of continual guidance and presence. Both images are used for the coming Messiah, fulfilled in Jesus Christ (see Luke 1:69).

verses.text: 'His enemies I will clothe with shame, but on him his crown will shine.'
verses.comment: The defeat of David’s enemies highlights the ultimate victory of God’s anointed. The perpetually shining crown indicates an everlasting kingdom—fulfilled in Christ the King, whose reign has no end.
